Description: Mould-made amulet in glazed composition in the shape of a scarab; crudely modelled back with elytra and prothorax marked by single line; at side, legs quite well-modelled and naturalistic; underside rubbed off, but likely with no decoration; pale turquoise blue glaze surviving in parts; cream core of smooth and fine textured; poor state of preservation.
Curator's comments: This type of scarab is very common during the Late Period. A second one, better preserved and more naturalistic, was discovered in Naukratis: BM 1888,0601.56 (EA66522). Another slightly plainer scarab, with no motif on the underside, was also discovered in Naukratis: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts RES.86.306. On this type of scarab, see: Hornung and Staehelin, E. 1976, 368, pl. 103 no. 913. On amulets of scarabs in general see: Andrews 1994, 59, esp. fig. 59f-g; Herrmann et al. 2010, 120-121 (type 69). Further examples published in Petrie 1914, pl. XI no. 92. Andrews, C. 1994, Amulets of Ancient Egypt, London. Herrmann, C., Staubli, T., Berger-Lober, S., Keel, O., Schönbächler, G. 2010, 1001 Amulett : altägyptischer Zauber, monotheisierte Talismane, säkulare Magie, Bibel+Orient-Museum, Liebefeld, Stuttgart. Hornung, E., Staehelin, E. 1976, Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Petrie, W.M.F. 1914, Amulets, London. Rowe, A. 1936, A Catalogue of Egyptian Scarabs, Scaraboids, Seals and Amulets in the Palestine Archaeological Museum, Cairo.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.250) (phase 3)
